results.title: Babar and Father Christmas
results.brief_description: In this delightful, fully animated tale, King Babar takes a journey in search of the legendary Father Christmas. But lurking along on Babar’s trail is Babar’s arch-enemy, Rataxes the Rhinoceros, who wants all of Santa’s toys for himself. Based on the book by Jean de Brunhoff and narrated by Laurent de Brunhoff. Rated: G

results.title: Babar's First Step
results.creator_credit: Michael Hirsh, Patricia Loubert, Clive A Smith and Raymond Jafelice
results.brief_description: Babar’s First Steps - Babar leads a happy and carefree life with his mother and all the other elephants in the jungle. But his life is shortened when a Hunter kills his mother and Babar must cope on his own. “City Ways” - Forced to run away from the jungle by the Hunter, Babar makes his way to the city, only to find it very dangerous and confusing. He is befriended by the Old Lady, who tries to teach him how to fit into her world. Rated: G

results.title: BabaKiueria = Barbeque area [DVD] (A)
results.creator_credit: Australian Broadcasting Corporation, Julian Pringle, Don Featherstone and Geoffrey Atherden
results.brief_description:
‘BabaKiueria’ takes a satirical look at black-white relations in late twentieth century Australia, with a comic depiction of a racial role reversal. In documentary (or ‘mockumentary’) style, the film’s presenter investigates white lives in the fictitious land of ‘BabaKiueria’ (‘Barbeque Area’), where white people are a minority, living under black laws and suffering from discriminatory practices and attitudes held by the black majority. Written by Geoffrey Atherden (‘Mother and Son’, ‘Grass Roots’), the film was awarded a United Nations Media Peace Prize in 1987.
Stars Michelle Torres, Bob Maza, Kevin Smith, Cecily Polson, Tony Barry.

results.title: Baba Yaga: a Russian fairy tale
results.brief_description: Presented as an on-line interactive storybook to read page by page with silhouetted illustrations, this Russian fairy tale tells the story of Vasilissa, her evil stepmother and Baba Yaga, the wicked witch who lives deep in the forest.

results.title: Baama: land of the red gums
results.creator_credit: Boolari Films and State Film Centre of Victoria
results.brief_description: An impression of the wild life along the River Murray, through the eyes of an old aboriginal fisherman (Aaron Briggs). Shows in particular the water birds of the swamps west of Albury; pelicans, herons, ibis, grebe, reed warblers, kites and cormorants. The connections of the various creatures and places along the river with tribal legend and tradition are recalled by the old fisherman. Photographed and recorded by David Corke and Peter Bruce. Narrated by John Morgan.

results.title: BaadAsssss cinema
results.creator_credit: Independent Film Channel, Minerva Pictures, Paula Jalfon, Colin MacCabe and Isaac Julien
results.brief_description: Informative and fun documentary about the origins and meanings of Blaxploitation cinema. A genre that originated with Melvin Van Peebles groundbreaking underground hit “Sweet Sweetback’s Baadasssss song”, blaxploitation refers to the slew of films that followed in its wake, revolving around, and often celebrating African American culture. In this work numerous actors, directors, and other players discuss their participation in Blaxploitation and what the genre meant to them personally, and culturally. Contemporary filmmakers, such as Quentin Tarantino, are interviewed about the influence of the genre upon their work. Interviewees include: Quentin Tarantino, Larry Cohen, Fred Williamson, Pam Grier, Melvin Van Peebles and Samuel L. Jackson.

results.title: B.W.D.
results.brief_description: Bacillary White Diarrhoea causes an annual loss to the British poultry industry of millions of pounds. The disease can be controlled by careful precautions, including blood-testing of stock and scrupulous attention to hygiene at all stages. This film explains the precautions necessary and gives details of the United Kingdom Ministry of Agriculture’s scheme to combat the disease.

results.title: B.B.C. television: the first 25 years
results.brief_description: Describes Britain’s pioneering efforts with this medium, showing how the demands of war accelerated technical development and how the post-war years nursed the nation-wide impact of this home entertainment. The opening of the first regular television service from Alexandra Palace, London, in 1936; highlights from popular programmes and the linking of the BBC service with Eurovision and Intervision 25 years later. A record of successful transmission from Britain to Australia indicates a path of future achievement.

results.title: Azzel
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Guy L. Cote, Peter Hollander, Peter McCaw and J.-P. Olivier Fougeres
results.brief_description: Azzel is the name of one of the first schools for nomads opened by the Niger Department of National Education. The film describes the traditional nomadic lifestyle of the Tuareg and the changes brought about in the lives of the children attending the government-run boarding schools.
